channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Deadly Explosions in China’s West
item.description: A series of explosions killed at least 31 people and injured 94 more on Thursday in Urumqi, the capital of the restive Xinjiang region, and officials called the blasts a terror attack.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: In this photo released by China's Xinhua News Agency, police officers stand guard near a blast site which has been cordoned off, in downtown Urumqi.

item.title: ‘Chasing Down Death’: India Seeks Answers on Premature Mortality
item.description: For the Million Death Study, researchers are interviewing families that lost loved ones at an untimely age to look for explanations.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ashok Kumar interviews Sushilamma in the village of Magadi in Karnataka, India, as part of the Million Death Study.

item.title: Russia and China Block Security Council Move to Prosecute Syria War Crimes
item.description: It was the fourth time that Russia and China, permanent members of the council, had used their veto power to block coercive action in the conflict.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Letter From Europe: NATO Steps Back Into the U.S.S.R.
item.description: With Libya in chaos and Afghanistan winding down, NATO is having a vivid fight over its future, which is actually a vivid fight about its past.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian soldiers in Crimea in March. NATO will be forced to take a position on Russia's annexation of Crimea during a summit meeting scheduled for September.

item.title: India Ink: Modi Activists in Karnataka Tell Bangalore Writer to Go to Pakistan
item.description: Supporters of Narendra Modi in Karnataka said that they had sent a ticket to Pakistan to a celebrated writer who spoke out against his candidacy.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: U.R. Ananthamurthy, a Kannada writer, during a press conference at the India stand of the Frankfurt Book Fair on Oct. 3, 2006.

item.title: Wary Europe Watches Vote in Greece for Signs of Protest
item.description: As Greece returns to the polls for European parliamentary elections, the vote has become a test of whether citizens believe the government’s assertion that the country is on the upswing.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: India Ink: India’s Import Limits on Gold Leave Jewelry Artisans Idle
item.description: Many of the estimated 400,000 goldsmiths have found themselves without enough work for the past several months, despite a robust consumer demand for gold jewelry, because of the country’s efforts to curb gold imports.
item.dc:creator: By RADHIKA OBEROI
item.media:description: A goldsmith working on a bangle at a workshop in Kolkata, West Bengal, in 2011.

item.title: India Ink: Modi Exits Gujarat but His Influence Lives on in New Chief Minister
item.description: A day after Narendra Modi, India’s prime minister-elect, resigned as the chief minister of Gujarat, one of his closest aides, Anandiben Patel, was sworn in as the first female chief minister of the state.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: Anandiben Patel, center, the new chief minister of Gujarat, speaking to reporters in Gandhinagar, on Wednesday.

item.title: Russia and China Block Security Council Move to Prosecute Syria War Crimes
item.description: It was the fourth time that Russia and China, permanent members of the council, had used their veto power to block coercive action in the conflict.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: As Elections Loom, Fighting Turns Deadly in Ukraine
item.description: The clashes came as NATO said for the first time that Russian forces may be preparing a limited and not yet confirmed withdrawal from the border area.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: An Ukrainian soldier stood next to a destroyed truck on Thursday at the scene of fighting near the village of Blahodatne, eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: As Xi speaks of conciliation, neighbors voice disquiet
item.description: Vietnam’s prime minister, during a visit to Manila on Wednesday, called on the world to condemn China for the “extremely dangerous situation” it had created.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung of Vietnam, left, with President Benigno S. Aquino III of the Philippines in Manila on Wednesday.

item.title: F.B.I. Closes Investigation Into Guantánamo Defense Aide
item.description: An investigation of a member of the defense team for a Guantánamo detainee accused of aiding the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks has been closed.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Thai Army Declares Coup, Citing Need to ‘Reform’ Nation
item.description: After detaining a group of political leaders on Thursday, the Thai military announced on television that it would “reform the political structure, the economy and the society.”
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: A television screenshot shows Army Chief General Prayuth Chan-ocha, center, making the announcement on Thursday.

item.title: Bloomberg Wins $1 Million Prize — and Gives It Back
item.description: The question was never whether he would keep the Genesis Prize money, but to whom he would give it.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q & A: Adam Segal on China, Cyberspies and the Moral High Ground
item.description: Adam M. Segal, an expert on China and cybersecurity at the Council on Foreign Relations, discussed the clash between the United States and China over cyberspying.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: The Internet security firm Mandiant identified this 12-story building on the outskirts of Shanghai as home to a Chinese military-led hacking group.

item.title: Euro Zone Economy Continues to Expand, Survey Suggests
item.description: Second-quarter data indicate the fastest pace of growth since the same period in 2011, according to Markit Economics.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Taliban Capture 27 People as Afghan Siege Continues
item.description: Another 13 officials awaited help as insurgents continued to besiege a district government complex in a remote corner of northern Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: South Korean Leader Dismisses More Aides After Ferry Disaster
item.description: President Park Geun-hye will replace the head of the intelligence agency and her top national security adviser as fallout continues from the ferry sinking.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: China Plans Security Checks for Tech Firms After U.S. Indictments
item.description: A plan for tighter scrutiny on tech companies doing business in China was announced by an agency that had threatened retaliation for cyberespionage charges.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Vote for European Parliament Seen as Bellwether for the Right
item.description: The balloting will span four days as voters in the 28 member states of the European Union choose their contingents.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Search for Missing Malaysia Airlines Plane Resumes
item.description: A Chinese ship will begin mapping the ocean floor before commercial vessels join in the search.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: China Factory Activity Shows Positive Signs
item.description: Manufacturing was at its strongest in five months in May, a preliminary HSBC survey showed, but because activity is still contracting, the outlook remains uncertain.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Dobrica Cosic, First Friend Then Foe of Serbia’s Milosevic, Dies at 92
item.description: A novelist and nationalist who served briefly as president of Yugoslavia as its breakup in the midst of sectarian war was already underway.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Dobrica Cosic, right, with Slobodan Milosevic in 1993.

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense confirmed the death of an American service member.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: World Briefing: India: Former Delhi Leader Jailed in Defamation Case
item.description: Arvind Kejriwal, who served briefly last year as Delhi’s chief executive, was jailed on Wednesday after refusing to pay a bail bond of around $171.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
